children.subject: +1 to this, 61C is pretty fundamental for many core 16x series courses (e.g. 161, 162, 164)

orig anon: thanks for the follow-up; I appreciate that! Now the question is, what would be the best possible solution in this case? Many thanks,

PS: I have taken an Assembly Language class at a community college (although not equivalent to UCB's 61C)
Taking 170 concurrently with 61C is pretty popular, so it would be reasonable to swap 170 and 162 on your plan.

I don’t have experience with a lot of these so I’m leaving the student answer open, but I would strongly discourage you from taking 61C and 162 at the same time. 162 relies on a good grasp of 61C. 

Also, as far as I know, 172 hasn’t been offered in several years and it’s not clear if it will be.

As a note, right now quantum computing is highly theoretical and any work regarding post-quantum cryptography is mainly math and proofs. This means that if you are looking for something applied, like the Cyber Grand Challenge, I don't think you will find that in post-quantum cryptography.

172 and 174 are not guaranteed to be offered when you want them to be and are almost utterly irrelevant to AI afaik, but they will be useful in building your proof and theoretical background.

If you would like a strong background in post-quantum cryptography, please consider taking more theoretical math/cstheory classes besides just quantum computing and cryptography. If you want to focus on AI, then I would place less emphasis on 172 and 174. If you want to focus on everything simultaneously, then I would schedule a cryptography class over 172/174.

history.content:
Dear EECS family,

I am an EECS junior and I have until December 2021 to graduate. I would wanna focus on "AI in (post-quantum) security"; to be specific, something like Cyber Grand Challenge. On top of that, I am planning on doing grad-school as well.

By the end of SP2020, I am gonna be done with all my HSS reqs.

Please let me know what you think of the schedule and if I am missing any important class(es):

SPRING 2020
CS 61B
CS 70
EECS 16B
HIST 137AC

FALL 2020
CS 61C (4)
CS 161. Computer Security (4)
CS 162. Operating Systems and System Programming (4)

SPRING 2021
CS 170. Efficient Algorithms and Intractable Problems (4)
CS 172. Computability and Complexity (4)
CS 174. Combinatorics and Discrete Probability (4)

FALL 2021
CS 188. Introduction to Artificial Intelligence (4)
CS 189/289A. Introduction to Machine Learning (4)

and now, a super long list of classes that seems related; let me know if i need to move any of these to my tentative schedule or take it in grad school:

CS 194. Special Topics (1-4)
CS 261. Security in Computer Systems (3)
CS 262A. Advanced Topics in Computer Systems (4)
CS 271. Randomness and Computation (3)
CS 276. Cryptography (3)
CS 171. Cryptography (4)
CS 261N. Internet and Network Security (4)
CS 294-168. Lattices, Learning with Errors and Post-Quantum Cryptography (4)
CS 294-175. Advanced Cryptography (1-4)
CS 285. Deep Reinforcement Learning, Decision Making, and Control (3)
CS 288. Natural Language Processing (4)
CS 289A. Introduction to Machine Learning (4)
CS 294-158. Deep Unsupervised Learning (1-4)
CS C280. Computer Vision (3)
CS C281A. Statistical Learning Theory (3)
CS C281B. Advanced Topics in Learning and Decision Making (3)
CS 287. Advanced Robotics (3)
EE 290P. Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering: Advanced Topics in Bioelectronics
CS 169. Software Engineering (4)
CS W169. Software Engineering (3)
CS 262B. Advanced Topics in Computer Systems (3)
CS C191. Quantum Information Science and Technology (3)

Many thanks,
history.subject: Course Planner
